Posts.Content: Caroline - I like your plan to get a second opinion at Duke. Sunshine - The MRI sounds like a good move. They can apparently tell a lot. For me it is more waiting, at least for a little while. The surgeon said that the pathology reports jive with what was seen on the mammogram but then we are left with the missing calcification in the biopsy specimen. She said that a calcification could have been picked up but than have gotten washed away. So I am supposed to get a comprehensive mammogram on my right boob and they are going to look to see if there are any calcification missing and they are going to check where the titanium marker was left - whether it was left at the site that was to be biopsied. If this doesn't pan out, then I have to go for an excisional biopsy. This is adding up to as lot of radiation exposure and bucks over a fleck of calcium.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hey Christina, We will be wishing you well. Just remember that a lot of women are going down this same path so you are not alone. Pat
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Christina, I'm sorry to hear about the complications but glad to hear the good news. The fact that this has dragged on so long for the group of us is tough, but it is good to have the support from each other. Pat P.S. For some reason I don't get notified anymore when there are postings to threads.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Caroline, I am sorry to hear the news but am glad to hear that it was found at what was possibly the earliest point possible. I still don't have a definitive answer on my problem but I will be thinking of you as a role model for pursuing this until we get an answer and then dealing with what they find. I assume you'll be having some sort of surgery and then followup of some sort, please keep us posted. This is a club that none of us want to be a member of, but the level of support that we give each other is unsurpassed. Pat
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: I was surprised to find that surgical biopsies were commonly done under general anesthesia. It is the rare procedure that is done otherwise. It is also my understanding that the anesthesiologist is the ruler when it comes to his or her specialty. A doctor can have a preference but it is your health situation and the surgery that determine what is used. I understand that nowadays, an anesthesiologist administers the drugs initially and then a certified nurse anesthetist takes over from there. However, the anesthesiologist must be in the area in case something happens. I would definitely call the hospital where you would be going for the procedure, tell them what you will be having done, and perhaps they can hook you up with someone from the very team that would be assisting. Nurse anesthetists are quite informed and take a lot of pride in their work.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Illinois Gal, Glad to hear the good news! Pat
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Remember that each person is different and statistics are just broad numbers. What will they be doing to try to make sure that you are in the good 50%? Also consider getting a second opinion - not about the statistics but about followup treatment. Good luck! ((((((HUGS))))) and prayers Pat
Posts.Title: Death from stage III cancer

Posts.Content: A significant amount of people have lived longer than 5 years with stage III - I think that the doc was trying too hard to be "balanced" in his assessment, and he ended up being negative to someone who needed more encouragement. Each person is such an individual that statistics mean very, very little. Also, many docs are better in how they relay info. I think that this one didn't realize the impact of his/her words. Sophie, you've got to taske statistics with a grain of salt. Pat
Posts.Title: Death from stage III cancer

Posts.Content: Quote: Originally Posted by CarolineNC I'll keep ya'll posted as to how Friday goes. I'm more nervous about what my results will be than the actual procedure. I bravely say right now... Caroline, just remember that if they find something not nice that they are going to have found it EARLY! Good luck, Pat
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Illinois Gal, What you may not realize is that there were a bunch of us that were experiencing the same journey for quite some time. I believe it mostly started with mammograms that showed microcalcifications. A couple of these ladies started the journey in mid February, I started mine in early March. And what we also had in common is that it was taking forever to find out what it was all about. Waiting for biopsies, waiting for results, waiting for appts with surgeons, and even more biopsies and mammograms and then more appts with surgeons. A couple of us had biopsy that either didn't suceed in obtaining tissue or it wasn't exactly the right tissue. Or the biopsy didn't tell the entire tale and there was still more to be found out. I think at least two or three of us still don't have an answer. We were all hoping and praying that the group of us would get lucky. We are all saddened by this news but I for one just have to rejoice that it was an early catch. I plan on following all of our stories and continuing to take comfort in not feeling alone with my 2-month saga. So our gratefulness is not a minimization of a BC diagnosis, but rather trying to stay strong and continue this difficult journey together. Welcome to the boards! This is a great group of people! Pat
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: CarolineNC, I'm just checking in to see how you are doing. I'm glad to hear that the rad treament is over. Good luck with the tamoxifan. Have you every thought about trying acupuncture if the side effects get to be too much. A young woman I know, about 42, said that her only problem was the night sweats. I go back for my 6-month post-biopsies followup in November. My outlook is different since my mom died. I think I would just do double mastectomy with no radiation. But I am probably depressed. Pat
Posts.Title: Radiation After DCIS - What Side Effects?

Posts.Content: I've also got an appt with a surgeon on April 20; I'll be thinking about you and wishing you well!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Illinois Gal, This is such a difficult "club" to belong to, but at least we are in it together. Best wishes, Pat
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Caroline, I will want to hear how your excision goes. Type of anesthesia, any discomfort, suggestions, etc. Thanks!
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: It wasn't entirely unexpected because she was going downhill over the last 2 years and especially over the last few months with big problems at the end of April through her death on June 6. But we really didn't know that this was going to be it until the last day. It is very likely that something in her waited until she knew that I was going to be OK. She apologized for not being able to be there for me with regard to my breast issues like she would have wanted to, but she gave me a great gift. One of my biggest fears in life was getting cancer and having no one there to be supportive. But over these last three months, I had to take care of myself but my parents were still there, but it was sort of like being alone with my health issues because my dad was wrapped up with taking care of my mom. So I did learn that I could emotionally handle serious health issues myself and that there are people out there - including on this board - that can provide the support that I need. I was blessed with good results this time but know that should something go wrong, I am not alone. Pat
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Sarasota and Caroline: Please update on your situations. I had a mammogram with a 1-cm lump which is enough of a worry in itself but I also have microcalcification and heterogenous something or other. I got the ultrasound-guided core biopsy on Thursday and they said I would get the news in three days. I am scared and alternate between trying to be ready for whatever results I hear and terrified crying. It seems that the results are not always cancer vs. no cancer. And some of the results still need to be treated by excision or they need to be watched and could turn into something bad. I am single and wish I had a significant other who doesn't care about breasts, but that is not my situation. Breasts are not that important to me but relationships are and I am afraid if I end up being one-breasted or grossly lop-sided (my smaller breast is the one with the problem) someone will think I am freakish. And I don't want all kinds of surgery just to please someone in the future. It helps knowing that I am not the only one going through this but the reality is that whatever the results I probably am going to have to continue dealing with this and I am pretty stressed out. Help!
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: The addendum to the pathologist's report said that the radiologist failed to obtain a tissue sample that contained a piece of the microcalcification, which means that they cannot be sure that they sampled the tissue that needed to be sampled, even though they did discover a benign condition. So I had to make the appointment with a surgeon (April 20). There could most likely be a recommendation for a surgical biopsy. I am hoping for a wait and watch recommendation (followup mammogram in 6 months). I selected a surgeon who considers breast surgery and monitoring benign conditions a specialty so hopefully I will get good advice. I really don't want surgery if it can be avoided, but I don't want to take chances either. I hope she has a clear recommendation.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Sarasota: You are making good sense. Caroline: I hope you are doing OK. Me: My 2nd biopsy (stereotactic) is on Tuesday May 25th and a week later I get the results. I am going zooey. The radiologist thought that it might be painful to get the calcs near my nipple/aeriola area. Looks like it is going to be three months from referral for mammo (March 8) to diagnosis (June 1). Pat
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: My sterotactic biopsy went OK, it didn't hurt. I have an appt June 1 with the surgeon and I will get the results then. I hear you loud and clear about just getting rid of them and being done with it. As of now, if I find out that there is something wrong, that is where my thinking is heading. However, I understand that after a mastectomy, some docs still recommend radiation. My breasts are just not that important to me but my peace of mind is. Keep us posted on how you are doing. I understand that most docs consider a second opinion to be a must after diagnosis, so keep pushing for it. Pat
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: The radiologist's office called after they got the pathologist's report - two benign breast conditions; however, I got a copy of the report from my doc who said that she wants me to follow up with a breast specialist. I have (1) dense stromal sclerosis (fibrosis) which increases my risk of breast cancer 1.5 to 2 times the norm, and (2) columnar cell changes which could either be nothing or it could be ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive cancer that the biopsy did not pick up. They did not say whether the CCC had atypia (or is the fibrosis the atypia?) Is the CCC related to the fibrosis or could they be possibly two separate issues? I bet I end up having to get a surgical biopsy, which could take a chunk out of my boob. My breasts are not all that important to me but I don't want to be grossly uneven. I have a feeling that I'm in for a long journey. Sign ...
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: With regard to this boob issue, I am getting irritated about having to live with this level of stress for so long. I just popped an Ativan. I guess if I were willing to go to any doctor I could have taken a step toward resolving this issue sooner but this is a serious matter that requires a good doctor. Nonetheless, this is a hideously stupid way to have to live. My appt with the surgeon is on Tuesday, April 20. (I believe another person on this list also has an appt with a surgeon on the same day - I'll be thinking about you and wishing you well!
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Went back to the surgeon who now wants to do a stereotactic biopsy because the ultrasound-guided core biopsy failed to pick up any microcalicifications. What I find disturbing is that the more worrisome of the clusters is not marked with a clip to show that it was biopsied in the first place. I called the radiology place and they said that it just appears that way because a mammo has to be viewed as three-dimentional and that is hard to do. However, the surgeon seems to be bothered. So now I am left with worrying that they never biopsied the correct place the first time around which makes it difficult for me to trust them. And I have heard not so good things about the stereotactic procedure so I am looking for advice - What do I need to know ahead of time. This is going on 2-1/2 months since my funky mammo.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: I'm so glad that the procedure went well!
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Sarasota, How did the stereotactic on April 29th go? Pat
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: So it looks as if after three months and three biopsy sites that that show nothing terrible I will be waiting until a 6-month followup. Five days after my mom learned that I would be OK with re to my breast issues, she passed away yesterday from unexpected kidney failure (she had been being treated for heart failure). She was my best friend and ally and I feel lost. This makes me fear death a lot less right now. Pat
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: My mammogram showed microcalcifications that were suspicious. Ultrasound-guided needle biopsy came back negative (benign adenoma; stromal fibrosis, columnal cell changes [no atypia]); however, the pathologist was not able to find a piece of the calcification in the tissue sample. So now the radiologist recommends that I have a surgical biopsy to be sure that they sampled the right area. I believe that there may be two separate areas of microcalcification. Has anybody experienced them not having picked up a microcalcification in the needle biopsy and then having to do followup? What did you do? Another option is to wait 6 months and get another mammogram. I have an appointment on April 20 with a surgeon who has a specialty in breast conditions, both benign and malignant. Is there anything that you wish you knew before you had a surgical biopsy? What questions do you wish you had asked? I'm very anxious and I fear pain.
Posts.Title: Excisional/surgical biopsies - Any advice?

Posts.Content: Thank you, ladies, for the support and encouragement. This waiting is difficult. I see the surgeon on April 20. We have such long waits and then when we find something out we are encouraged to make a decision soon. The tension is exhausting. Sophie, how did your surgery go (was it on Monday)?
Posts.Title: Excisional/surgical biopsies - Any advice?
